definition: multitude of enemies, few friends (idiom from Mencius)/heavily outnumbered/beaten by the weight of numbers
enemy/to be a match for/to rival/to resist/to withstand
abbr. for 眾議院|众议院[Zhong4 yi4 yuan4], House of Representatives
many/numerous/crowd/multitude
variant of 眾|众[zhong4]
I/me/my
few/scant/widowed

sentences.english: Outnumbered twenty to one, the defending Tang forces soon ran out of arrows.
sentences.chinese: 由于敌众我寡，唐朝军队的箭很快就用完了。

sentences.english: Outnumbered 20 to one, the defending Tang forces soon ran out of arrows.

definition: the multitude against the few, a wide disparity (idiom from Mencius); heavily outnumbered/unequally matched/overwhelmed by weight of numbers
the few are no match for the many/heavily outnumbered/facing impossible odds (idiom)
enemy troops/hostile forces/CL:股[gu3]
fight to the death/desperate struggle
to fight with all one's might
to annihilate/to wipe out completely/to exterminate
to rely on natural barriers (for one's defense)
military strength/armed forces/troops
(to resist the enemy) relying on inaccessible territory
many men, a great force (idiom); many hands provide great strength/There is safety in numbers.
seriously injured
a blood soaked and hard-fought struggle (idiom)
to guard/to hold a fortified position/entrenched
to go all out for sth at risk of one's life
to prepare an ambush/to waylay
out of ammunition and no hope of reinforcements (idiom); in desperate straits
